mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Community-based Analysis for Identifying Population Relevant to Pollutants Mitigation in Natural and Engineered Process

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Environmental pollution is of significant concern for public health and safety. Pollution source identification and mitigation are of great importance in waste management. Despite the extensive application of techniques in pollution identification and control, much remains to be learned on how to improve the accuracy of pollution source tracking, and how to promote the process efficiency of pollution treatment. We believe the microbial population are become essential in pollution source tracking and pollution mitigation. Therefore, we applied the anaerobic treatment as the engineered process and stream water as natural processes study object. In the engineered process, antibiotic resistant genes (ARGs) were regarded as biomarkers to investigate the persistency of anaerobically treated animal wastewater. Moreover, we detected the key populations that can help transform both animal wastewater and industrial wastewater to methane. In the natural process, we firstly successfully cleared the sample definition of wastewater in microbial source tracking, a basic source tracking gap in the current study to date. Then we evaluated urban stream health under human perturbations, which verified an ‘Anna Karenina principle’ for stream water microbiomes. These findings would provide new insights into source tracking from the microbial ecological aspects to environmental studies.
mods:mods.mods:note: microbial community, anaerobic digestion, metagenomics, wastewater, stream, antibiotic-resistant gene
